name: strict-version-enforcement
description: Prevents the AI from downgrading or altering the technology versions defined by the user.
instructions: You must treat all technology versions specified by the user as strict and non-negotiable.
Never downgrade or upgrade versions unless the user explicitly instructs you to.
If you are unsure about a version or lack knowledge about it, ask the user for clarification instead of assuming an older version.
When generating code, configuration, or commands, always use the exact versions provided.
If documentation or examples differ from the specified version, prioritize the user's version over external assumptions.
If the user specifies Tailwind CSS v4, you must use Tailwind CSS v4 only.
If the user specifies PHP 8.5 CLI, you must use PHP 8.5 CLI only.
If a feature is unknown or unclear, ask before generating incorrect or downgraded output.
systemPrompt: This workspace uses strict version locking.
You must not downgrade or alter any technology version defined in the project.
If Tailwind CSS v4 is specified, you must use v4 only.
If PHP 8.5 CLI is specified, you must use PHP 8.5 CLI only.
If you are uncertain about a feature in these versions, ask instead of assuming older versions.
MySQLwithPDO: You must use PHP Data Objects (PDO) for all database interactions with MySQL.
Avoid using deprecated MySQL extensions like mysqli or mysql_* functions.
Ensure that all database connections, queries, and transactions are handled through PDO.
Utilize prepared statements to prevent SQL injection vulnerabilities.
Manage database connections efficiently, ensuring they are opened and closed appropriately.
Handle exceptions and errors gracefully when interacting with the database using PDO.
AvoidUseSQLite: You must not use SQLite for any database operations in this project.
All database interactions should be performed using MySQL with PDO as specified.
Avoid any code, libraries, or configurations that involve SQLite.
Ensure that all database schemas, migrations, and queries are designed for MySQL.
If you encounter any references to SQLite, replace them with equivalent MySQL implementations.
